sprigTree.title: Résumé
sprigTree.body:
Hi. I'm Jim Kang. I'm a software developer in Cambridge, Massachusetts. You can reach me at jimkang@gmail.com.

I've worked on commercial products that were run by millions of users, as well as software for art and concept exploration.

This is an overview of my work. If you just want to go straight to my publicly available code, here are my Github repos and my NPM packages.

children.title: Web and mobile era
children.body: This part of my career started around 2008 and continues today.

children.title: Spotify
children.body:
I currently work at Spotify on a team that builds music recommendations. Some products we've built are the automated This Is playlists (greatest hits playlists for artists that stay fresh by updating daily based on listening patterns) and Time Capsule. Some things I build:

  • Internal apps (web apps, Chrome extensions, Electron apps) for evaluating and adjusting algorithmically-generated content
  • The occasional prototype for potential new experiences
  • External promotional web sites
  • A process that analyzes and composes 2500+ images each day
  • External promotional web sites
  • Qualitative user surveys

The job involves traditional full-stack web development (JS, CSS, nginx, Node, Python), but much of the work navigating a very unique infrastructure. Spotify makes significant usage of protocols that aren't http, containerizes extensively, and is on the Google Cloud platform for example.

children.title: PayPal
children.body:
I worked at PayPal on the Shop team.

The Shop site serves coupons from various PayPal partners to hundreds of thousands of people per day. The front end is a single-page app built in AngularJS. The back end is a cluster of NodeJS servers that talk to various PayPal services to manage the coupon and user information.

We used TDD, pair programming, and Git Flow very heavily. And, perhaps less effectively, Scrum.

children.title: NPR
children.body: I was part of the team that worked on Composer, a music data warehousing app written in Node and Backbone used by over 200 NPR member stations. I added this app's first automated tests (in order to safely do a big refactor to add OAuth to the API) and learned quite a bit about TDD as a result. Our team used a Kanban process and an unusually high level of design-development integration.

children.title: Modo Labs
children.body:
The company built mobile apps for big institutions like universities and handled wrapping up their existing data sources to make them easily mobile-consumable.

Mostly, I worked on iOS apps, with some web service development here and there. In addition to bread-and-butter Cocoa Touch development, we explored Core Animation, automating media file encryption, and web view-centric native apps.

children.title: Voter Activation Network
children.body: Their business was centered around a massive data warehousing web application. I helped with maintenance on that and also built a WYSIWYG form editor for the web. Later, I worked on back and front ends for their canvassing iOS app, MiniVAN Touch.

children.title: Obama for America
children.body:
I spent six weeks as a "Data Fellow" during the 2008 presidential campaign. We automated manual tasks and wrote programs to look through voter contact history to find good targets for calls. 

Indiana went blue, which it normally doesn't. It felt good, I met great people, and I saw how the relatively simple application of technology could make a big impact.

children.title: Windows era
children.body: This era lasted from about right after college (1999) to 2007.

children.title: GN Resound
children.body:
GN Resound is a hearing aid company. Hearing aids are small digital sound processors. Audiologists can calibrate and gather data from them by connecting them to a computer.

I was on the team that worked on that software, which at the time, was a C++ COM/ATL-based Windows desktop application.

children.title: InstallShield
children.body:
This is where I learned to write code that worked in real-world situations when run by thousands (millions in a few cases) of real users. I worked on a team that built a few different SKUs of an IDE that let developers author "setups," programs that installed their software onto computers.

The IDE was a Windows application written in C++.

children.title: Projects
children.body:
A few personal project highlights:

  • Sprigot is the web app you see right now. It's a way to write and present branching documents.
  • An interactive explanation of quadtrees. I built this because I was using a quadtree for another app and realized, I didn't really understand quadtrees. It was pretty well-received! Non-programmer-, non-mathematics-types have told me they understood quadtrees after trying it.
  • @godtributes is a merciless generalization of the "BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD!" meme. It's an interactive Twitter bot that, despite its limited modes of expression, has inspired a lot of followers to fill in the blanks with their imaginations. Here's a nice review of it on I Love E-Poetry that discusses its poetic appeal.
  • @linkfinds is another Twitter bot that composes Zelda scenes in which Link finds various objects from the web.
  • 1st Edition Advanced Dungeons & Dragons had a charming quirk in it. Every experience level for every class had a separate name. Named Levels is a web app that tries to generate those names for any possible "class" you could think of.
  • annoy-node is Node bindings for Annoy, a popular Approximate Nearest Neighbors implementation in C++. The output of many machine learning processes is a lot of n-dimensional vectors representing things like words or songs. This Node module lets you use that kind output in JavaScript.


If you want to see more of my projects, you may want to take a look at this visualization. Though it is a work in progress, it's update daily, so it should usually be complete.

children.title: Perspective
children.body:
Here are my main principles for building software:

  • Write tests. Write enough to easily tell if something is broken when you change it but not so much that the tests become a burden unto themselves. Change program [code to be more testable instead of making tests extremely elaborate.
  • Try to stick to code and tools you understand, even in third-party libraries. Sometimes, that can't be helped, but you will likely be forced to understand code you used later under pressure if you don't understand it now.
  • Make sure the code you're considering writing is actually necessary.

children.title: Keywords!
children.body:
For better or worse, a lot of people look for this in a résumé. So, here it is:

- JavaScript
- Mostly functional, closure-centric programming
- Problems and benefits of prototypal inheritance
- Node.js
- Test-driven development
- Modular architecture
- LevelDB
- NPM
- CSS 3, Flexbox, animations
- Browserify
- Objective-C
- Git, Git Flow
- Tape, Mocha
- Backbone.js
- C++
- SQL
- HTML (v1-5)
- At least a 1X engineer, maybe even 1.1X

children.title: About this format
children.body: This document is organized as a tree. This view is presenting it as indented list, but you can check out a more expansive view of it. More about Sprigot (the app presenting this document).
